text: In Greek mythology, Eidothea or Idothea (Ancient Greek: Εἰδοθέα) was the name of the following women: *Eidothea, a sea goddess, daughter of Proteus, the Old Man of the Sea. She told Menelaus how to hold her father so that he could not escape.Homer. Odyssey, iv.360ff * Eidothea, a nymph of Othreis who mothered by Poseidon, Eusiros of Cerambus who was borne up into the air on wings by the nymphs escaping the flood of Deucalion.Antoninus Liberalis. Metamorphoses, 22 vs Cerambus * Eidothea or Eidothee, a Carian woman, daughter of King Eurytus and possible spouse of Miletus who bore him Byblis and Caunus.Antoninus Liberalis. Metamorphoses, 30 vs Byblis * Eidothea, second wife of Phineus, king of Thrace. She was the sister of Cadmus and thus, maybe the daughter of Agenor, king of Tyre. Eidothea put out the eyes of her stepsons (Gerymbas and AspondusScholia on Sophocles, Antigone, 981, 989 ed. Brunck) with the sharp shuttle in her blood-stained hands and also caused to imprisoned them.Scholia on Sophocles, Antigone, 989Sir Richard C. Jebb. Commentary on Sophocles: Antigone, 966 == References == Category:Greek goddesses Category:Nymphs Category:Princesses in Greek mythology Category:Queens in Greek mythology
title: Eidothea (Greek myth)
